dt: {bc}an illegal act for which someone can be punished by the government

dt.t: It's a {wi}crime{/wi} to waste good food.

pt: {sc}offense{/sc} {sc}sin{/sc} {sc}vice{/sc} {sc}crime{/sc} {sc}scandal{/sc} mean a transgression of law. {sc}offense{/sc} applies to the infraction of any law, rule, or code.

pt.t: at that school no {it}offense{/it} went unpunished

pt: {sc}sin{/sc} implies an offense against moral or religious law.
{sc}vice{/sc} applies to a habit or practice that degrades or corrupts.
{sc}crime{/sc} implies a serious offense punishable by the law of the state.
{sc}scandal{/sc} applies to an offense that outrages the public conscience.

pt.t: a career ruined by a sex {it}scandal{/it}

et: Middle English, "wrongdoing, sin," borrowed from Anglo-French, going back to Latin {it}crīmin-, crīmen{/it} "accusation, charge, indictment, source of an accusation, misdeed, offense," probably from {it}crī-{/it}, variant stem of {it}cernere{/it} "to sift, discern, decide, determine" + {it}-men{/it}, resultative noun suffix (probably originally "decision," then "judicial decision, indictment") {ma}{mat|certain:1|}{/ma}
shortdef: an illegal act for which someone can be punished by the government; especially : a gross violation of law
a grave offense especially against morality

dt: {bc}any of various crimes (such as assault or defacement of property) when motivated by hostility to the victim as a member of a group (such as one based on color, creed, gender, or sexual orientation)

shortdef: any of various crimes (such as assault or defacement of property) when motivated by hostility to the victim as a member of a group (such as one based on color, creed, gender, or sexual orientation)

dt: {bc}a crime (such as genocide or maltreatment of prisoners) committed during or in connection with war

shortdef: a crime (such as genocide or maltreatment of prisoners) committed during or in connection with war —usually used in plural
